creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Anslie Ketchin grew up in Winnsboro, "mainly famous as the place where Cornwallis wintered before surrendering during the Revolutionary War." Her grandfather was a Confederate soldier who was accidentally poisoned by spoiled corn after his capture. Her father was an architect who learned to build the homes he designed because "during the Depression, if you just designed homes, you starved." Ketchin herself worked for J. Edgar Hoover's FBI during World War II, later writing for the Charlotte Observer.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Cotney joined the Civil Air Patrol after Pearl Harbor was bombed. When the Marines opened up enlistment to women, "I was down to the office that that very morning. Unfortunately, my father got wind of what I was doing, and talked me out of it." But Cotney really wanted to serve, so on June 1943, she enlisted. She did boot camp at Camp LeJeune, then became a radio operator at Parris Island. "We were the first wave of female Marines to arrive," she said. "They were so happy to see us." The motto for female Marines at the time was, "free a man to fight," and the male Marines at Parris Island could finally go overseas. Cotney met her future husband at Parris Island, before he shipped out to join the fighting at Guadalcanal. They were married when he returned to recover from battle injuries.

"For the first two years after the war, I was pulling metal slivers out of my face and throat," he said.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Johnny Dieter served on the USS Montpelier during the American invasion of Saipan, Tinian and Guam. "Before we headed in, we practiced on an island that had been cleared of Japanese," he said. "We lobbed some shells in there, and all of a sudden, they were firing back." After VJ-Day was declared, he served with occupation forces in Japan. "Hiroshima, the destruction was horrible," he recalled. "The Japanese really wanted us to see what we had done. They would load open-backed trucks with victims and follow us around as we toured the devastation."

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: When war broke out, Greenlaw could have accepted deferment because his job was vital to the country. But he wanted to serve, and soon joined the Navy. He was put in charge of developing landing craft for the Pacific invasion, and worked mainly in the Eastern Fingerlakes. "The crews on these ships were so green," he recalled. "They had to get some experience before they headed to the Pacific." One night, Greenlaw took watch so the crew could get some sleep, and they left an exhaust valve open. "The topdeck basically exploded," Greenlaw recalled. "I woke up three days later in the hospital, and could only eat baby food for a year." Greenlaw's extensive injuries meant he couldn't serve again before war's end.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Dorothy Grant Eaddy and Anna Grant Myers grew up in Murrells Inlet, SC. Their parents were both schoolteachers who stretched the household budget with fresh vegetables and seafood. "I can remember dad going out and fishing all night, coming back early in the morning, and that boat would be full of fish." The sisters recall when a causeway ran right along the Inlet in front of everyone's home and their washerwoman, Aunt Nelly, did the wash in a giant black pot. Both sisters married and settled back in Murrells Inlet when older.

The destroyer later spent its time shelling gun emplacements on enemy-controlled Pacific Islands, "softening them up" for landings by US Marines.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Writer John Brock has a memory both eidetic and nostalgic as he looks back to his childhood during the Great Depression. He lived with his extended family on the edge of Charlotte, but spent plenty of time visiting his farming grandparents. When the Depression hit, his father was laid off, but bravely started his own business, which did well until his death. "We didn't have much, but we didn't expect much, so we didn't miss much." When he was four, there was a knock on the door, and a man was there, begging for food for his sick daughter. "That just seared the effects of the Depression on my little soul," he said.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Charles Houseman grew up in Vienna, Virginia and he was 12 when WWII began. "We all pitched in," he said. "Every eligible draftee in our town headed out, so there were a lot of shoes to fill." Houseman and other teens volunteered for the fire department, and canvassed neighborhoods for usable metal. They sat in the aerial observer tower and identified and called in planes that were heading toward Washington. In the summers, they took buses to area farms and brought in the crops. "One row would be a 13-year old kid. The next row would be a German POW," he recalled. The war years had an affect on Houseman: when he came of age, he joined the military - and stayed for 24 years.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Hazzard tried to enter the Navy in 1942, but was deferred because of an old burn scar. He piloted his tug boat to see a friend in North Charleston who was an Admiral of a submarine fleet, and was in the next week. He served aboard the USS DuPage, an attack transport that deployed Marines during Pacific Island invasions. The ship participated in 16 invasions, and Hazzard said the most harrowing was that of Pelelieu, a bitter battle that raged for 12 days. During that invasion, a nearby barge full of ammunition was hit on the port side by 500-lb bombs, and limped into a landing before its crew jumped off. Hazzard waded out to the barge, felt his way through the smoking engine room, and cut the fuel lines. "If that barge went up, it would have blown everything nearby to bits," he recalled. His heroics earned him a Silver Star for conspicuous gallantry in action. During the invasion of the Lingayen Gulf in 1944, the DuPage was hit by a kamikaze aircraft, killing all on deck - except Hazzard. "I was listed among the dead until I came to," he recalled.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Joe Engel was a young teen in Poland when the Germans took over his town, made all the Jews register, and took 18 young Jewish men to the marketplace, where they were summarily shot. Engel's family packed what they could carry on their backs and escaped to Warsaw, where they were captured and sent to the ghetto. By age 14, Engel was an inmate at Auschwitz, where he spent every day digging ditches. "In my block, you would find people dead in their bunks every morning. When you left the building, you would see people hanging from the electric fences - they had committed suicide." In 1945, when the Allies came close, the surviving inmates were stuffed into cattle cars and sent toward Germany. Engel knew they would be killed there, so one night, he jumped from the train and hid in the snow, and was eventually rescued by the Allies.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Daniel Hearl grew up on a farm close to Bucksport, SC. When war broke out, he joined the Navy and was sent to the Brooklyn Navy Yard to sail on the new USS Moale, which headed for the Pacific. The destroyer participated in carrier strikes on Manila and Leyte Island. "Every morning, the Jap bombers would visit, but didn't hit much because all the ships in the fleet would blow smoke." The worst action Hearl saw was near Leyte, where the ship next to his was blown in half and his own ship was strafed, injuring 25 men. After landing troops all over the Pacific, the Moale headed to Tokyo, where the most destruction was done by a set of 40-foot waves.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Williams was working for International Paper when Pearl Harbor was bombed. His twin brother promptly joined the Coast Guard, but Lide waited a little longer and joined the Navy. After training in landing craft operations, he joined the Third Beach Battalion and headed to Auckland, where his unit ran landing maneuvers with the Marines. Then his ship joined a convoy headed to the Gilbert Islands, where his first landing operation was in the hard-fought Battle of Tarawa. "Our landing craft was hit by a shell, and we had to spend the whole first night circling in the water." The next morning wasn't much better - his landing craft was able to pull up under a pier, but there were dead Marines everywhere. He later joined ship's company and participated in six invasions, including those of the Marshall and Admiralty Islands. After the war, a battle with tuberculosis helped steer him into the decision to become a doctor.

sourceResource.description: MIllett graduated high school in Maine in 1941, and soon was helping build Liberty Ships in the Maine shipyards. He enlisted in the Marine Corps in 1942, and after boot camp at Parris Island, headed to air tactical and gunnery training. His squadron of B25 crews headed to New Caledonia, then Emirau, scouting and patrolling recently taken Japanese islands. When Japan surrendered, Millett spent a few more months in the Pacific Islands, helping to strip downed planes before they were buried. He got back to the US on December 1, 1945.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: By 1941, Frank Dunlap was on the USS President Coolidge heading to Guam, then Manila. He was in a tent city there when he heard Pearl Harbor had been bombed. Two days later, the Japanese were bombing Manila, and US forces, after months of battling back, made a last stand at Bataan. When the US surrendered there in April 1942, Dunlap and 70,000 other American and Filipino troops were forced to march 65 miles to makeshift prison camps - the Bataan Death March. "Anyone who fell out was bayoneted, beheaded or shot in the temple," Dunlap recalled. "And so many men were falling out because of disease or heat stroke or hunger and thirst." Dunlap spent three and a half years at camps in the Phillipines and Japan, starving, beaten, and working twelve hour days in 112-degree heat. One time, he was hung from his thumbs for two days. "My toes touched the ground, so I could still crawl back to my hut when they cut me down," he said. "Lots of men couldn't move, and they were beheaded on the spot." When Japan surrendered, Dunlap was at a mining camp in Japan. "The camp colonel read the proclamation, and we all hit the ground and cried and hollered."

sourceResource.description: Charles Mattox was attending the University of Richmond when WWII began. He volunteered to be an Air Corps Cadet, and went in as soon as he was old enough - January 1945. He ended up as a gunner on a B-24 in the Pacific Theater, and served on missions to "soften up" Japanese-held islands, including Okinawa, before their invasion. "The thing I remember about Okinawa was the rats. They would run over our legs at night." Immediately after the war, Mattox served in the Occupation Army in Japan.

sourceResource.description: Wynn was in college when Pearl Harbor was bombed. She graduated and went into defense work at a large air force depot in Warner Robins, Georgia. When the Women's Marine Corps began to recruit, she signed up and was soon doing her boot camp stint at Camp LeJeune. She then headed to Congaree Field, an auxiliary air base outside Columbia, where the Navy Corsairs were training. She worked in a squadron office, keeping track of the endless soldiers at home and overseas. "I think it was a wonderful experience," she says. "I made some good friends - I wouldn't take anything for it."

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Laura Atkinson grew up in Wampee, SC during the Great Depression. To help pay for college, she taught at a school so small, there were only six children in first through third grade. She married a Methodist minister and they moved to Murrells Inlet. "He preached at a circuit of five churches, and was promised a salary of $1,000 a year. Half of that was given to him in the form of produce, chickens and canned goods," Mrs. Atkinson says. When the couple arrived in Murells Inlet in 1943, it was extremely rural, with dirt roads, no electricity, and one phone for the whole community, located at Eason's Store.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Edgie Huggins grew up in a sharecropping family, in Plantersville, SC. When she was very small, her great grandmother, a former slave, got caught in a briar patch and wasn't found until the next morning. Edgie remembers making brooms from scratch, getting out of school to watch her brothers and sisters, and working into the night to get the crops in. "Every day I'd plow and pick cotton and grade tobacco, to keep from hiring people, because we couldn't afford to pay them." Spending money was made picking briar berries and huckleberries and riding a wagon into town on a Saturday to sell them.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Wolfe joined the army in 1939 - "more during the Depression than wartime." He was stationed near Long Island and did guard work for the World's Fair before being sent to Central Park to set up searchlights and gun emplacements in case of German attack. He later fought in Oran in the North Africa Campaign, then joined the D-Day effort in the 4th infantry division. "We worked our way up the Normandy coast through the hedgerows - I was a forward observer's radio operator." His unit later pushed on to Belgium and Germany and had reached the Siegfried Line when Wolfe was wounded. While recovering in England, Wolfe fell in love and applied for a marriage license. The army's response - he was sent right back to Paris to serve in the Occupation Army.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Wollman joined the Navy in 1942, leaving college to serve. While in navigation school in Sampson, New York, he volunteered for a "mystery mission," complete with a psychiatric evaluation, then trained on a hidden base in Rhode Island. He became part of the first wave of PT boats in the Pacific, running fast-attack missions near enemy-held islands. "They were all about speed," Wollman recalled. "Get in there, throw the torpedoes, get out." One night, his boat ran right into a Japanese destroyer, and Wollman woke up five days later in a tent hospital. He was asked for details on how he rescued a comrade that night, but had no memory of the incident.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Tripp graduated high school in Ithaca, New York in 1941, and served as an airplane mechanic in the Civil Air Corps. When the Marines opened their ranks to women, she joined against her father's wishes. She went through boot camp at Camp LeJeune, then to Cooks and Bakers School. She became a Sergeant in charge of a mess hall at LeJeune that served 300 people every day, and lived in the barracks with the Marine Corps Band. She later ran a mess hall at Henderson Hall in Washington, DC, finally leaving the service in 1946. "I joined because I wanted to do my part," she said. "We all wanted to."

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Bill Johnston enlisted in the Marine Corps as soon as he was old enough, and became a demolitions specialist with the 7th regiment of the 1st Marine division. His first battle was on the Pacific island of Peleliu, where his unit was pinned down by enemy fire for a whole day after landing. His unit joined the landing on Okinawa and fought for months before the island was secure. "And the rain - we were soaking wet for three weeks. When we dropped back and got to take our shoes off, our socks had disintegrated and our skin was peeling off." Johnston was offered a purple heart for shrapnel injuries he sustained, but he wouldn't take it after watching his friend lose his leg in the same battle.

When Ed grew up, he studied at the New York Institute of Finance and bought a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, working there for 30 years. "In the early days, we were all pencil, paper and voices," he said.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Ackerman fought as part of the 47th Infantry Division in the European Theater, seeing the most action at the Rhine River in Germany. "We met a lot of resistance from rifles and bombs there," he recalls. "After we crossed the bridge, they blew it up. We had to dig in under heavy fire for a week, until they could put a pontoon bridge up." One day, he was walking next to a tank and was hit by schrapnel. He was put in a body tourniquet and was rushed to a hospital in France. "That was the end of the fighting for me," he said. He had to spend months in the hospital stateside before discharge.

Along the way, the couple befriended Tom Yawkey and his wife, and the generous Red Sox owner ended up helping them establish the Smith Medical Clinic in Pawleys Island.

sourceResource.description: Bertha Cole grew up in the upper part of Georgetown County and went to school in a one-room schoolhouse called Williams Hill. Her father had a large tobacco farm and store, both of which were lost during the Great Depression. The family was further devastated when their roomy farmhouse was destroyed in a fire. "I was a grown girl before we even had electricity," she said. She had four children and her husband worked at International Paper.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Louise Bennett grew up on Georgetown's West End during the Great Depression. "I remember, when we came here, the (Atlantic Coast Lumber Company) was right down the street. There were huge yards of lumber all through the West End." She attended Howard School and she and classmates would walk to class because few people had cars. Everyone was so poor, Louise, like many classmates, wanted to quit school to work, but her father wouldn't let her.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Baxley was working at West Virginia Pulp and Paper when he heard about the bombing at Pearl Harbor. As soon as he turned 17, he joined the Navy and was trained to pilot Higgins Boats (LCVPs), used extensively in amphibious landings. He crossed the Atlantic in a converted luxury liner, and landed just east of Monaco. From then on, the Higgins boats were in the thick of it, often rescuing survivors from larger vessels that were sunk by German submarines. His unit followed the army through the Mediterranean, shuttling German prisoners of war, unloading men and artillery, and dodging sniper bullets from shore. His unit was in the invasion of Algiers, Sicily and Salerno, then hauled reinforcements to Tripoli. After D-Day, his group sailed to the English Channel, then up the Seine, bringing replacements and ordinance to battles in France.

He ran a landing craft during battles in the Pacific Islands, once grievously injured and knocked unconscious in the water after a floating mine blew up his boat.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Charlie McConnell was one of the youngest of ten children, and watched his four brothers enter the service ahead of him. He got his parents' permission to join the Navy and, the week after high school graduation, was at boot camp in Virginia. He became a Bosun's Mate Third Class and embarked from Boston on a brand new LCSL-117, headed for the Pacific Theater. His ship patrolled the shoreline off Okinawa with a destroyer escort, shooting down four Japanese kamikaze planes during duty. His ship weathered two typhoons - during one, a nearby destroyer was broken in half and McConnell's ship engaged in a desperate rescue mission. Later, a shell got caught in his ship's magazine and exploded, pounding McConnell's leg with shrapnel. He was offered a purple heart for the wound, but refused it in honor of the sacrifices his brothers had made.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Writer John Brock has a memory both eidetic and nostalgic as he looks back to his childhood during the Great Depression. He lived with his extended family on the edge of Charlotte, but spent plenty of time visiting his farming grandparents. When the Depression hit, his father was laid off, but bravely started his own business, which did well until his death. "We didn't have much, but we didn't expect much, so we didn't miss much." When he was four, there was a knock on the door, and a man was there, begging for food for his sick daughter. "That just seared the effects of the Depression on my little soul," he said.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: James Rider had just finished playing a high school ball game and was sitting in a diner when the news that Pearl Harbor had been bombed came over the radio. He signed up the next day, and ended up in the Army Medical Corps. His first station: a stateside hospital,where he sterilized instruments and set up operating trays. He was sent to North Africa in 1942, and was stationed in Casablanca, where he ran a medical supply warehouse and guarded the city's tent hospital. "As medics, we weren't allowed to have guns," he recalled. "We armed ourselves with big tent pegs." He later served onboard a hospital ship, shuttling injured soldiers and prisoners of war from North Africa to the states. He then joined the 200th Hospital Ship Complement, bringing home wounded soldiers from England, and later, the Pacific.

sourceResource.description: Rodgers joined the National Guard in 1933, and remained with his unit until called into active duty in 1941. By 1943, they were in an artillery unit with the 1st Division in North Africa, protecting troops that were pushing Germans out of the seaports. After the Germans were defeated there, the group loaded up on an LST and headed to Italy.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Bob Hendrick was born in 1918 in Conway, and worked in his father's grocery store until he was drafted, landing on the beach at Normandy and fighting his way through France until grievous injuries sent him back stateside in 1945. He moved to Murrells Inlet in the late '50s, when it "was still just a simple fishing village." The civic-minded Kendrick spent 20 years on Conway City Council, is a strong member of the Shriners, and founded the Murrells Inlet Boat Parade.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Howard Vincent grew up in tiny Lynchburg, South Carolina and, like every teen in town, joined the fight as soon as he was old enough. ironically, he reported for duty to the Navy in 1945, on the day Japan surrendered. "Here I am on a troop train, heading to duty, and there are parades and guys kissing girls everywhere. I made a joke that Japan had awfully good intelligence if they already knew I was coming." For Vincent, the biggest memory of the war was how everyone in his 500 member town pulled together, with victory gardens, war bonds, rationing and saving metal. "We all fought World War II."

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: At 17, Mike Bivona headed off to a naval training base on Seneca Lake in New York, where he was assigned to crew a PT boat. He landed at a stateside naval base and his company escorted convoys coming home from Europe. After VE Day, his base was decommissioned and he prepared to head to Pearl Harbor to join the Pacific Theater, but Japan surrendered. "I found out after the war that the guys from my boot camp who weren't assigned to PT boats were all put on the same heavy cruiser. It was hit by a kamikaze pilot and destroyed."

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Stewart Swift grew up in Washington D.C. where his father had a job in the federal government. In 1943, as soon as he turned 18, he joined the Army Air Corps as an aviation cadet. He first served on an air base in Liverpool, England, armoring fighter planes in-between missions. He joined the 75th Division just after the Battle of the Bulge, and helped clear German troops through the Ruhr Valley. One of his worst memories is of breaking into a work camp at Belsen, where dead prisoners were "stacked like cordwood." the German soldiers had run away and left them to starve.

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Smith grew up in Newberry, SC, and heard about the bombing of Pearl Harbor on his Philco radio. He joined the reserves in 1942, was called up in 1943, and headed to Europe, where he joined an anti-tank company in the 87th Division. His unit traveled through France into Belgium, shelling German holdouts in forts, attacking German-held towns and villages, and doing recon work at night. The division reached Germany, engaging in numerous battles before Smith was hit in the back by shrapnel, which lodged in his chest. He was tagged to head to a field hospital, but had a good meal, grabbed a gun, and went after a German sniper. "I was too used to fighting. I just couldn't disengage."

creator: Georgetown County Library
sourceResource.description: Harold McCarthy grew up on the edge of the National Cemetery in Philadelphia, where his grandfather was caretaker. After Pearl Harbor was bombed, his brother joined the Army and his sister joined the Marines. Harold was only 17 and pestered his parents until they wrote a note to let him join. He spent three months at engineering school, then boarded a transport ship in San Francisco, bound for the Pacific. He worked in the engine room of the USS Essex, where "it was 120 degrees. You couldn't touch anything metal." His ship was an aircraft carrier with major gun emplacements and, during the years McCarthy was on it, the ship's planes shot down over 1,000 Japanese planes, and the ship itself sank dozens of Japanese planes and ships. The Essex participated in operations throughout the Pacific, severing enemy supply lines, bombarding enemy-held islands, and sinking Japanese ships. In its long WWII service, the ship was only hit once, by a kamikaze pilot that crashed into the flight deck, killing 15 and wounding 44.

sourceResource.description: Richard Manning left Davidson College to join the service, and went into Naval aviation training. Halfway through, the Marines conscripted him to be an aviation instructor. Manning later joined a Corsair unit, "the hottest airplane there ever was, at the time." His unit was on notice to fly missions over Japan when the atomic bombs were dropped. A small contingent, including Manning, flew over Hiroshima and Nagasaki just after they were bombed. "It was obliterated, no houses, no trees," he recalls. "It was just too damn terrible."
